stem_html: What information could you obtain by looking at a velocity vs. time graph?

answers.feedback_html: The slope of the velocity vs. time curve is acceleration.

A velocity vs. time graph does not indicate the direction of motion of the object. For that, a frame of reference would be required. As an example, moving to the right on the graph is the positive direction.
It is not possible to find out the reference frame from the velocity vs. time graph.
The area under the velocity vs. time graph tells us the displacement, but not the shortest path between two points.

stem_html: How would you use a position vs. time graph to construct a velocity vs. time graph and vice versa?

answers.content_html: Slope of position vs. time curve is used to construct velocity vs. time curve, and slope of velocity vs. time curve is used to construct position vs. time curve.
answers.feedback_html: Yes, the slope of a position vs. time curve is used to construct a velocity vs. time curve, but constructing a position vs. time curve from the slope of a velocity vs. time curve is not possible.

answers.content_html: Slope of position vs. time curve is used to construct velocity vs. time curve, and area of velocity vs. time curve is used to construct position vs. time curve.
answers.feedback_html: The velocity can be calculated from the slope of the position vs. time graph, and displacement can be calculated from the area under the curve of velocity vs. time graph.

answers.content_html: Area of position vs. time curve is used to construct velocity vs. time curve, and slope of velocity vs. time curve is used to construct position vs. time curve.
answers.feedback_html: The slope of velocity/time curve will not give you displacement.

answers.content_html: Area of position/time curve is used to construct velocity vs. time curve, and area of velocity vs. time curve is used to construct position vs. time curve.
answers.feedback_html: It is correct that area under the curve for a velocity vs. time graph will give displacement, but constructing a velocity vs. time curve from the area under the position vs. time curve is not possible.

stem_html: An object is moving along a straight path with constant acceleration. A velocity vs. time graph starts at 0 and ends at 10\,\text{m/s}, stretching over a time-span of 15\,\text{s}. What is the objectâ€™s net displacement?

answers.feedback_html: It can be calculated from the area of the velocity vs. time graph.
Try to calculate the area under the velocity vs. time graph.
Recall the formula for the area of a triangle and apply it in this question to calculate the net displacement.

answers.content_html: cannot be determined from the information given
answers.feedback_html: The displacement can be calculated from the area under the velocity vs. time graph.
